column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=This trend started to worry me with e-mail first .
#Text=Because of spam most ISPs stopped relaying mail and I began to have some trouble sending e-mail while on travel .
#Text=To send mail you have to know the local smtp server .
#Text=But which hotel receptionist can tell you that ?
#Text=They stare blankly at you , incapable of understanding that you do not use web mail , i.e. that you do not have your messages on a server .
#Text=Money is virtual , it is a number on a computer in a bank somewhere .
#Text=We trust the bank : nobody has gold coins in a sock under the mattress .
#Text=But we have been working on the banking establishment for a few centuries .

#Text=The last time we had a great crash ( depression of 1929 ) not only a large number of people died of hunger , but it helped bring about the most totalitarian state we ever witnessed ( the Third Reich ) .
#Text=Since those days we have learned a lot , painfully and with lots of mishaps .
#Text=Therefore now we think that we can trust the banks and the economists with our money .
#Text=The breakthrough came from government controls and international conventions .

#Text=With our data it is now as it was with money about two centuries ago : everything is in the hands of uncontrolled private companies , without any legal framework , to say nothing of international agreements .
#Text=But my data are a part of myself .
#Text=I want to know how my data are managed , by whom , where , and with what guarantees .
#Text=Money I may lose but then I grow my potatoes in my garden .
#Text=You speak of a web-Renaissance .

#Text=That would be a brilliant light that would let us see that in the information-driven era we need to build new social structures , new forms of creating trust and we need more transparency in the processes of society .
#Text=The principle behind wikis such as Wikipedia provides similar functionalities to early web browsers that were web editors at the same time .
#Text=To which extent is this analogy correct ?
#Text=The one great difference , maybe , is that wikis run on servers , but I can of course put a wiki on my home computer or laptop .
#Text=It 's not really wysiwyg but that is not so important .
#Text=Do you see wikis as a viable long-term model , or do you expect something else to emerge ?
#Text=On the subjects of wikis , do you refer to Wikipedia ?
#Text=I use the Wikipedia often .
#Text=I also contribute here and there .
#Text=A very great work , looked at with a lot of jealousy .
#Text=In almost all comments about the Wikipedia I perceive in the background some jealousy and intolerance .

#Text=There seems to be a strong reaction from those who derive their prestige from " secret " knowledge and consequently find it rather scandalous that everything is now not only lying around to be read but also often debunks their prejudices .
